pends upon the molecular condition of the ignited 
gas and the corresponding modification of the 
vibrating ether within it. Certainly, at the present
state of science, we have not the least indication 
of the connexion of the molecular constitution 
of the gas and the kind of light emitted by it.
But we may assert with confidence, if one spectrum of a given gas be replaced by quite a 
different one, there must be an analogous change 
of the constitution of the ether, indicating a new 
arrangement of the gaseous molecules. Consequently 
we must admit either a chemical decomposition 
or an allotropic state of the gas. Conclusions 
derived from the whole series of our researches 
led us finally to reject the first alternative and to 
adopt the other.
26. The same spectral tube exhibits in any 
succession whatever as often you like each of 
the two spectra. You may show it in the 
most striking way by effecting the intercalation 
of the Leyden jar by means of a copper 
wire immersed in<s>to<\s> mercury. As often as 
the wire is taken out of the mercury we 
shall have the spectrum of bands, as soon 
as the communication is restored the spectrum 
of bright lines. Hence we conclude that 
the change of the molecular condition of Nitrogen 
which takes place if the gas is heated beyond 
a certain temperature by a stronger current 
does not permanently [alter its chemical
